trans-unit.source: Get Started with mobile app backends for HTML/JavaScript apps | Azure App Service Mobile Apps
trans-unit.target: Get Started with mobile app backends for HTML/JavaScript apps | Azure App Service Mobile Apps

trans-unit.source: Follow this tutorial to get started using Azure mobile app backends for web app development in HTML5 and JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Follow this tutorial to get started using Azure mobile app backends for web app development in HTML5 and JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to an HTML5/JavaScript web app using an Azure Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to an HTML5/JavaScript web app using an Azure Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: You will create both a new Mobile App backend and a simple To do list web app that stores app data in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You will create both a new Mobile App backend and a simple To do list web app that stores app data in Azure.

trans-unit.source: A screenshot from the completed app is below:
trans-unit.target: A screenshot from the completed app is below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screenshot of completed app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screenshot of completed app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Completing this tutorial is a prerequisite for all other Mobile Apps tutorials for HTML apps.
trans-unit.target: Completing this tutorial is a prerequisite for all other Mobile Apps tutorials for HTML apps.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free Mobile Apps that you can keep using even after your trial ends.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free Mobile Apps that you can keep using even after your trial ends.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: [Visual Studio Community 2013] or a later version.
trans-unit.target: [Visual Studio Community 2013] or a later version.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter Mobile App in App Service. No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter Mobile App in App Service. No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Portal], click Browse All > Web Apps, then click the Mobile App backend that you just created.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Portal], click Browse All > Web Apps, then click the Mobile App backend that you just created.

trans-unit.source: In the Mobile App backend, click All settings and under Mobile App click Quickstart > HTML/JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: In the Mobile App backend, click All settings and under Mobile App click Quickstart > HTML/JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Under Download and run your server project in Create a new app, click Download, extract the compressed project files to your local computer, and open the solution in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Under Download and run your server project in Create a new app, click Download, extract the compressed project files to your local computer, and open the solution in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Build the project to restore the NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: Build the project to restore the NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) is a way for your web-based app to indicate from which domains requests are safe and should be permitted by the browser.
trans-unit.target: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) is a way for your web-based app to indicate from which domains requests are safe and should be permitted by the browser.

trans-unit.source: You must add a CORS entry for every web site that will access your Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: You must add a CORS entry for every web site that will access your Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: You control your CORS settings by using the standard ASP.NET Web API behaviors.
trans-unit.target: You control your CORS settings by using the standard ASP.NET Web API behaviors.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Enabling Cross-Origin Requests in ASP.NET Web API</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Enabling Cross-Origin Requests in ASP.NET Web API</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: By default, the client quickstart project that you will download from the portal runs on localhost on port 8000.
trans-unit.target: By default, the client quickstart project that you will download from the portal runs on localhost on port 8000.

trans-unit.source: Because of this, you will next enable CORS for http://localhost:8000 in the server project.
trans-unit.target: Because of this, you will next enable CORS for http://localhost:8000 in the server project.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio in the Tools menu, click NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console, select Nuget.org as the Package source and execute the following command in the console window:
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio in the Tools menu, click NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console, select Nuget.org as the Package source and execute the following command in the console window:

trans-unit.source: This installs the CORS support required by the backend.
trans-unit.target: This installs the CORS support required by the backend.

trans-unit.source: Open the App_Start/WebApiConfig.cs project file and add the following using statement:
trans-unit.target: Open the App_Start/WebApiConfig.cs project file and add the following using statement:

trans-unit.source: Next, add the following code to the WebApiConfig.Register method after the HttpConfiguration is created:
trans-unit.target: Next, add the following code to the WebApiConfig.Register method after the HttpConfiguration is created:

trans-unit.source: Save your updates.
trans-unit.target: Save your updates.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will deploy your CORS-enabled project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will deploy your CORS-enabled project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Back in the blade for your Mobile App backend, click All settings and under Mobile App click Quickstart > HTML/JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Back in the blade for your Mobile App backend, click All settings and under Mobile App click Quickstart > HTML/JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Under Download and run your HTML/Javascript project in Create a new app, click Download and save the compressed project files to your local computer.
trans-unit.target: Under Download and run your HTML/Javascript project in Create a new app, click Download and save the compressed project files to your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the location where you saved the compressed project files, expand the files on your computer, and launch one of the following command files from the server subfolder.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the location where you saved the compressed project files, expand the files on your computer, and launch one of the following command files from the server subfolder.

trans-unit.source: launch-windows (Windows computers)
trans-unit.target: launch-windows (Windows computers)

trans-unit.source: launch-mac.command (Mac OS X computers)
trans-unit.target: launch-mac.command (Mac OS X computers)

trans-unit.source: launch-linux.sh (Linux computers)
trans-unit.target: launch-linux.sh (Linux computers)

trans-unit.source: On a Windows computer, type R when PowerShell asks you to confirm that you want to run the script.
trans-unit.target: On a Windows computer, type R when PowerShell asks you to confirm that you want to run the script.

trans-unit.source: Your web browser might warn you to not run the script because it was downloaded from the internet.
trans-unit.target: Your web browser might warn you to not run the script because it was downloaded from the internet.

trans-unit.source: When this happens, you must request that the browser proceed to load the script.
trans-unit.target: When this happens, you must request that the browser proceed to load the script.

trans-unit.source: This starts a web server on your local computer to host the new app.
trans-unit.target: This starts a web server on your local computer to host the new app.

trans-unit.source: Open the URL http://localhost:8000/ in a web browser to start the app.
trans-unit.target: Open the URL http://localhost:8000/ in a web browser to start the app.

trans-unit.source: The client app is configured to connect to your Mobile App backend in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The client app is configured to connect to your Mobile App backend in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type meaningful text, such as Complete the tutorial, in Enter new task, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type meaningful text, such as Complete the tutorial, in Enter new task, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Running the app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Running the app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This sends a POST request to the new Mobile App backend hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This sends a POST request to the new Mobile App backend hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Data from the request is inserted into the TodoItem table in the Mobile App schema.
trans-unit.target: Data from the request is inserted into the TodoItem table in the Mobile App schema.

trans-unit.source: Items stored in the table are returned by the service, and the data is displayed in the second column in the app.
trans-unit.target: Items stored in the table are returned by the service, and the data is displayed in the second column in the app.

trans-unit.source: You can review the code that accesses your mobile service to query and insert data, which is found in the app.js file.
trans-unit.target: You can review the code that accesses your mobile service to query and insert data, which is found in the app.js file.
